image.altText: Scott Morrison, wearing a blue tie, frowns while standing in the PM's courtyard

props.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison announces he will retire from politics at the end of February, ending a 16-year career in federal parliament, including four served as prime minister.

title.children: Former prime minister Scott Morrison set to quit politics after 16-year career

image.altText: A composite of two women tennis players and one male tennis player, all gesturing with delight

props.synopsis: Eight remain in the men's and women's draw for the Australian Open, with the first day of quarterfinals being held at Rod Laver Arena. Follow live.

title.children: Quarterfinals begin at Melbourne Park with Sabalenka, Gauff and Djokovic in action

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ABC Tennis podcast discusses players facing death threats
How the seeds have gone in the women's singles
How the seeds have gone in the men's singles

image.altText: 'Australians have the right to know': PM Albanese on missing cabinet documents

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has given the strongest indication yet that the stage 3 tax cuts will be expanded to benefit lower-income earners.

title.children: 'Everyone will be getting a tax cut': PM hints at stage 3 expansion

image.altText: Woman in a green top and hat standing in a desert.

props.synopsis: Legal aid services in Alice Springs are experiencing a lawyer shortage, leaving some people who have been charged with crimes to navigate the justice system alone.

title.children: Indigenous Australians in Alice Springs face legal crisis with potentially dire consequences

image.altText: Sophie holds a football and pouts at the camera.

props.synopsis: At just 13 years old, Sophie had a bad experience on the footy field, but is speaking out because she's proud of her Aboriginal heritage. It's a story experts say is too common.

title.children: Sophie was called a racist name playing footy – she wants her story to be heard

image.altText: ADF personnel stand behind a Chinook helicopter.

props.synopsis: As Townsville is positioned as the new capital of the Australian Army, the federal government says the city's defence bases need modern, fit-for-purpose facilities and infrastructure to support critical capabilities.

title.children: $35 million to upgrade Townsville defence bases as hundreds of troops move north

props.synopsis: The Australian government has imposed sanctions against Russian man Aleksandr Ermakov over his role in the Medibank Private data breach.

title.children: Australian-first sanctions target Russian accused of Medibank hack

image.altText: Aleksandr Ermakov sitting in a chair in what appears to be a high-end bottle shop

props.synopsis: The Australian government is using Magnitsky-style sanctions for the first time to punish a Russian man over the 2022 Medibank Private data breach. But what impact will they have on him and how will the move help curb cyber crime?

title.children: Australia is sanctioning a Russian over a cyber crime but will it have any impact?

image.altText: Tropical cyclone forecast track map January 23

props.synopsis: The system is now forecast to cross the coast on Thursday between Cardwell and Airlie Beach.

title.children: Cyclone models predict more than 1 metre of rain as system tracks toward Queensland

image.altText: A drone shot looking down at a flooded road as a person in the distance walks through the water covering the road

props.synopsis: The year has barely started and extreme weather events are already in the headlines. Here are some more big environment issues to keep an eye on.

title.children: Five hot environmental issues to watch out for in 2024 from greenwashing to turbulence over turbines

image.altText: An aerial view of flooding at Timber Creek.

props.synopsis: Potential evacuations of remote communities with the help of the Australian Defence Force had been flagged by authorities but NT Chief Minister Eva Lawler says they are no longer required.

title.children: Floodwaters receding in NT communities while supply chain issues continue

image.altText: A woman sitting in a car.

props.synopsis: A Perth woman thought she was calling her insurer to make a claim, but found herself caught up in a scheme that whisked her car away and cost more than $6,000 to undo.

title.children: How insurance 'claim farmers' can tow your car away and charge thousands for its return

image.altText: Kurtley Beale outside court wearing a suit and tie

props.synopsis: Rugby union player Kurtley Beale denies sexually assaulting a woman in a Bondi Beach pub in 2022.

title.children: Kurtley Beale told woman he 'really wanted' to have sex with her before alleged sexual assault, court told

image.altText: A radiologist uses a magnifying glass to check mammograms for breast cancer

props.synopsis: With one in seven Australian women likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer, concern is growing about the wait times for diagnostic mammograms around the country.

title.children: 'I thought I could get it sorted in a couple of days': Lengthy mammogram waits, out-of-pocket costs for women

image.altText: Aleksandr Ermakov wearing a light blue button up shirt, sitting at a desk with coloured balloons above him

props.synopsis: The government publicly names the 33-year-old Russian citizen and "cyber criminal" it says is behind the the data breach but doesn't go into specifics about his role in the attack.

title.children: Who is Aleksandr Ermakov, the man linked to the Medibank Private cyber attack?

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

props.synopsis: A new survey shows that nearly every Australian is cutting back on expenses — whether it be on entertainment or life's basics like food.

title.children: Evidence suggests households are under extreme cost-of-living stress and a new worry is creeping in

image.altText: Woman with short red hair sits on a couch leaning on her hand

props.synopsis: When Linda Neil was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, she feared her creative days were over. Then a revolutionary treatment changed her life.

title.children: Deep brain electrodes, adjusted by wi-fi, are bringing 'miraculous' results to Parkinson's patients

image.altText: A female tennis player in a multicolour top punches the air and screams in victory

props.synopsis: Dayana Yastremska wins hearts, Daniil Medvedev entertains and a protest stops play. Here are five quick hits from day nine at Melbourne Park.

title.children: Five quick hits — Qualifier's dream run ends former champion's slam, while Medvedev charms with insightful interview

image.altText: A large grey Royal Air Force aircraft is sheltered by a green canopy with two people in yellow vests standing by it.

props.synopsis: The strikes targeted an underground storage site, missiles and other military capabilities.

title.children: US and UK carry out new strikes against Houthi rebels

image.altText: ADF personnel stand behind a Chinook helicopter.

props.synopsis: As Townsville is positioned as the new capital of the Australian Army, the federal government says the city's defence bases need modern, fit-for-purpose facilities and infrastructure to support critical capabilities.

title.children: $35 million to upgrade Townsville defence bases as hundreds of troops move north

image.altText: Joe Biden stands in front of a US flag

props.synopsis: The New Hampshire attorney general's office is investigating a recorded message mimicking Joe Biden, attempting to disrupt and suppress voting in the state's upcoming primary election.

title.children: US state investigates AI robocall mimicking President Joe Biden's voice to suppress voter turnout

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell

props.synopsis: Cricket Australia looks into how Glenn Maxwell ended up in an Adelaide hospital following a gig involving cult band Six & Out.

title.children: CA investigating incident that saw Maxwell hospitalised after Six & Out gig

image.altText: A graphic showing a man coughing, a rapid antigen COVID test and three spike proteins

props.synopsis: As school holidays come to an end and people return to work, Australians are reminded to take precautions against another "substantial" wave of COVID-19.

title.children: These three charts show the latest COVID-19 numbers from around Australia

image.altText: A crowd of people gathered outside a temple

props.synopsis: One of the most divisive chapters in India's history has come to an end with the opening of a new Hindu temple on the site where an ancient mosque was torn down. While Narendra Modi's supporters see it as a victory, Muslim Indians are fearful it could stoke old tensions.

title.children: Right-wing protesters tore down an ancient mosque with their bare hands. Now Modi is opening a temple there

image.altText: The front of a yacht heading into a big wave with three crew on board in yellow jackets.

props.synopsis: A mismatched bunch of thrill seekers on a world marathon sailing challenge take shelter in Northern Queensland to avoid wild weather in their path.

title.children: Yachts in global race forced to bunker down at Airlie Beach as potential cyclone approaches

image.altText: A representation of virtual currency Bitcoin and US banknotes.

props.synopsis: The decision by the US Securities and Exchange Commission to approve bitcoin exchange-traded funds was a decade in the making that's legitimised crypto — and experts say it won't be long before Australia follows suit.

title.children: Whether you understand it or not, bitcoin 'is here to stay' — and experts say it's about to get even easier to invest

image.altText: Drone view of housing rooftops and roads

props.synopsis: Australian households' debt-to-income ratio has reached 185 per cent of disposable income. Is it time to impose tougher lending restrictions? Read about this and how the Australian share market is trading higher after another optimistic streak on Wall Street that pushed US stocks to a fresh record high. Follow live.

title.children: Australian households more indebted, so do we need tougher lending rules?

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Do we need tougher restrictions on lending to households?
Mining revenue rises again off the back of higher prices for iron ore, coal

image.altText: People holding protest signs crowd a room where people sit at a circular table

props.synopsis: Israeli forces have stormed a hospital and placed another under siege in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis, as families of the Israeli hostages storm a parliamentary committee.

title.children: Families of Israeli hostages storm parliament demanding politicians do more to free loved ones

image.altText: Protesters in Tehran tear an Israeli flag up.

props.synopsis: The latest round of attack and response in the Middle East threatens to push the region into a broader war that has a common element ... Iran.

title.children: Iran's changing strategy sparks fear of regional war in the Middle East

image.altText: a mine site with a big truck and white rock

props.synopsis: The sudden evaporation of hype and hot air in the energy transition industry may leave many who plunged into critical minerals in a critical condition, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Critical minerals prices are crashing — and there could be some high-profile casualties

image.altText: A man in winter gear walks through a blizzard toward three yellow tents.

props.synopsis: In a whitewashed corner of one of the world's coldest continents, Australian scientists are living in tents and undertaking some of the most ambitious research in 20 years.

title.children: Scientists previously thought this corner of Antarctica was 'immune' from climate change — but now it's losing ice
